Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is a Category 1 responder under the Civil Contingencies Act 2004; this requires the Trust to have plans in place for responding to incidents and to ensure business continuity.

In recent years the country has experienced more dramatic weather changes with less distinctive seasons, this means that we are experiencing weather systems which are having greater impacts on communities and health, it is forecast that if this continues we will see more extreme weather with greater impacts.

It is recognised that both Heatwave and Cold Weather cause's excess deaths and that vulnerable groups such as older people, the very young and those with long term conditions are particularly vulnerable to the effects of weather changes.
Adverse weather can occur at any time of year, and can include prolonged periods of cold weather, Snow fall, flooding, exceptionally high winds and Heatwave.

The Met Office weather alert service operates in England throughout the year in association with the Department of Health in order to warn and inform the public and responders including health care providers.
Purpose of the plan
The purpose of the adverse weather plan is to allow Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is to:
Respond to periods of prolonged cold or hot weather that may have an impact on the health and wellbeing of the general population.
Respond to periods of extreme wind or rain that may cause damage to buildings or the local area.
Ensure staff are aware of measures to protect themselves and patients during adverse weather
Take any other actions necessary in relation to an emergency.
Scope
This plan covers both adverse weather from Heat and from Cold and applies to the entire Trust.
Definitions

table_items.text: Unfavourable or Harmful Weather Examples are: Heatwave, severe thunderstorms, flooding, severe, snow or hail storms, severe fog, hurricanes etc.

“There is no universal definition of a heat wave and the term is relative to the usual weather in the area or local threshold. The definition recommended by the World Meteorological Organisation is when the daily maximum temperature of more than five consecutive days exceeds the average maximum temperature by 5 °C, the normal average”. Source: UK Climate Projections

Cold weather is defined for the purpose of the plan according to two measures: When the mean temperature of 2o C or below is predicted together with the extent and spread of ice and heavy snow. These two measures are used to assess and inform regional ‘cold weather' alerts via the Met Office.

Is defined: as snow that is expected to fall for at least two hours. Geographical extent is not considered, and sometimes the event can be localised. For the Trust, it is important that the Strategic (Gold) and Tactical (Silver) commanders consider how heavy snow may affect staff travel arrangements, safety of the site (in terms of slips trips and falls), temperatures of departments and the possible increase in trust attendances and the effects on pre-existing long term health conditions.

Ice forms when rain falls on surfaces at or below zero; or already wet surfaces fall to or below zero. The ice is usually clear and difficult to distinguish from a wet surface. It usually forms in sheets. Warnings are issued when any depth of ice is expected over a widespread area. Warnings will also be issued after a snowfall when compacted snow is expected to cause an ice risk. Widespread indicates that snow or icy surfaces will be found extensively over an area as defined in the Met Office alerts.

data.text: Risk factors and health related illness

NHS England / Improvement and Public Health England have developed national guidance for both heatwave and cold weather planning, along with a range of information booklets for both the public and health care providers on staying well.

Certain types of environment may exacerbate the risk from extreme heat or cold, such as poorly maintained or insulated accommodation, lack of efficient ventilation or heating, or work places where employees are exposed to the elements.
Along with public information NHS England / Improvement and Public Health England run national vaccination programs for the very young, older people and those with long term conditions.

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust will undertake a programme of seasonal vaccinations for its staff to ensure that they and patients are adequately protected. Seasonal flu vaccine is made available to all staff.
The vaccination programme is led by Occupational Health and includes drop in clinics and mobile vaccination staff who attend the wards in order to cover the greatest number of staff.
Occupational Health will monitor the uptake of vaccinations against seasonal influenza according to staff groups. This information will be reported (percentage uptake and actual numbers of staff).
Roles and responsibilities
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has in place effective arrangements to respond to an incident that has the potential to affect service provision.
Accountable Emergency Officer

The Accountable Emergency Officer takes responsibility for Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response on behalf of the organisation. This includes ensuring that the Trust is properly prepared and resourced for dealing with an incident
Directors and Senior Managers
Directors and Senior Managers are responsible for ensuring that:
Business Continuity plans are developed and in place for their areas and functions of responsibility.
Business Continuity plans are cascaded to staff who are given appropriate training.
Plans are tested and reviewed annually or sooner as appropriate.
Head of Emergency Planning, Resilience and Response (EPRR)
Head of Emergency Planning, Resilience and Response (EPRR) will work with the Accountable Emergency Officer to ensure the following actions are in place;
The Trust's process for adverse weather planning and Business Continuity is understood and followed
Plans and guidance is distributed to Directors, Departmental and Service Leads and Heads of Nursing.
Distribute Met Office Weather alerts as they are received in order that appropriate actions according to plans can be taken.
Clinical Service Leads/ Service Managers:
Clinical Service Leads/Service Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service areas and for monitoring the impact on the service.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward complies with this document.
Head of Estates and Facilities
The Head of Estates and Facilities is responsible for:
The gritting of traffic access routes, car parking areas and pedestrian walkways on site premises.
Identifying any potential issues relating to periods of severe cold weather (including snow and ice) and ensuring appropriate action is taken to reduce the risk.
Implementing business continuity plans as appropriate
Staff
All staff must make themselves familiar with their individual roles as set out in:
This plans procedures and actions described.
Individual's services / departmental Business Continuity plans.
National alerting periods
The periods for heatwave alerts and winter alerts are:
Heat Health Watch - This system operates in England from the st June untill 15th September.
Cold Weather Watch - This system operates in England from st November untill 31st March.
Communication
The Civil Contingencies Act 2004 provides a duty on category 1 responders to warn and inform the public before, during and after an emergency, this includes during periods of cold weather.

The emergency planning team for Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is signed up to receive the Met office weather alerts for both Heatwave and cold weather. When the triggers for each of these are met for local action, the team will ensure the alerts along with a copy of the most current plan are distributed across site managers/departmental leads.
Overall responsibility for notification of the Alert Status and implementation of the policy rests with EPRR officers
Wards and Departments raise awareness of preventive action people can take, both throughout the year and during adverse weather to keep warm/cold (as applicable)

The trust must ensure attention is especially given to ensuring that key public health messages reach vulnerable groups and those who care for them (e.g. caregivers of the chronically ill, parents of young children) in a suitable and timely way. This can be done through the communications team and also through ward/department staff.
Wards and Departments will engage through face to face contact with patients, such as within clinics or upon discharge.
Public health messages and advice on financial support and benefits can be found on the www.gov.uk/phe website.

In the event of serious inclement weather affecting the Trust's service provision, the Communications Team can use internal and external communication channels to inform staff and the public. The Communications Team will make use of Social Networking, Internal Communications Systems (such as the display screens in outpatients).
The trusts Communications Team will regularly upload information on the hub on the impact of adverse weather from reports received from the Met Office.
NHS England and NHS Improvement will issue advice and information to the public and health care professionals, both before and during adverse weather.

Heatwave alerts

9.4.1  Heatwave alerts are received by emergency planning leads and clinical site managers. Should the triggers be met, the alert is distributed wider to departmental leads and senior managers on call. Out of hours heatwave Met Office alerts are also received by the clinical operations team who will action the plan.
Example of a Heat-Health Watch Alert
Generic actions at each level:
9.5.1 Responsibilities at Level 1

During the summer months, social and health care services ensure that information regarding heatwaves and what to do both in preparation and during a heatwave are available to both the public and staff.
9.5.2 Responsibilities at Level 1 and 2

The Met Office will develop and publicise the regional threshold temperatures in preparation for Level 2 and will ensure that forecasts are disseminated when there is a 60% chance that the threshold will be exceeded.
Public Health England will issue general advice to the public and healthcare professionals, including details of what to do at Level 2 and 3.
Public information leaflets to be made available to patients and visitors, and fact sheets to be made available to health care professionals.
Staff awareness to be raised identifying the very significant heat-related health risks.
9.5.3 Responsibilities at Level 3: Heatwave action

This is triggered as the Met Office confirms that the threshold high temperatures have been reached in any one region or more. The forecast will include the likely duration of the heatwave, the likely temperatures to be expected and the probability of other regions exceeding their threshold.
9.5.4 Responsibilities at Level 4: Emergency

This is reached when a heatwave is severe and/or prolonged that its effects extend outside health and social care, such as power and water shortages, and/or where the integrity of health and social care system is threatened.
At this level, illness and death may occur among the fit and healthy and not just high risk groups.

In the event of a major incident being declared, all existing emergency policies and procedures will apply. The Cabinet Office will ensure that a lead government department is nominated to coordinate the central government response.

Response arrangements therefore need to be flexible, in order to adapt to the nature of the challenge and other circumstances at the time while applying good practice, including lessons from previous emergencies.
Level 4 Emergency may be considered under the following conditions:
Prolonged or severe heatwave
Problems arising with schools, transport, water, and food supplies
Interference with critical national infra-structure and media concerns
Concerns over number of deaths
Patient area temperature monitoring
9.6.1 Temperatures should be recorded on the ‘temperature monitoring sheet within this document or an appropriate alternative computer generated report. See appendix 1.
9.6.2 At Level 2 alert monitoring should commence in clinical areas in order to ascertain any naturally cooler areas, which could be utilised during a heatwave.
9.6.3 Check that indoor thermometers are in place and recording sheets printed to measure the temperature four times a day once a Level 3 alert has been received for our region
9.6.4 The temperatures within some site buildings can also be monitored by ‘Building Management Systems, (BMS)' which is a central computerised temperature monitoring system.
9.6.5 Temperature monitoring will be carried out for all Wards and Clinical areas four times daily by ward staff when a Level 2 alert is issued by the Met Office.
9.6.6 The temperature will also be recorded four times a day once a Level 3 alert has been received for our region.

9.6.7 All Ward Sisters, service leads and Clinic Managers will be required to complete a Heatwave Management Checklist as seen in Appendix 2 at Level 3 Alert. These will be utilised by Managers / service leads and Heads of Nursing /Lead Nurses to cascade and will include heatwave guidelines to assist in keeping environment, patients and staff cool.

9.6.8 Those areas Identified as having naturally cooler rooms, or patient areas which have active cooling systems in place should be used for patients that are identified as vulnerable patients due to the effects of heatwave particularly those with chronic/severe illness, on multiple medications, or who are bed bound.
9.6.9 In the cases of heatwave whereby temperatures exceed 26ºC, high risk individuals should be moved to a cooler area at temperatures 26ºC or below.
At risk groups
There are certain groups that are particularly at risk during a heatwave, these include:
Older people, especially women, over  years;
Babies and young children, especially those under four years old;
People suffering from mental ill health, those with dementia, and those who rely on help to manage day-to-day activities;
People who are taking certain types of medication to control cardiac function or electrolyte balance
People with infections
People using psychoactive or illicit drugs
People who are bed bound;
People who have previously experienced problems adapting to extreme heat
People who suffer from chronic ill health
People who are unable to adapt their behavior in order to keep cool.
People who are obese
Additional groups at particular risk in the acute hospital setting are those who are:
Post-operative patients
Nil by mouth patients
Patients with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular conditions
Obesity
Patients with malnutrition
Patients with diabetes
Parkinson's disease and difficulties with mobility
Respiratory insufficiency
Renal insufficiency
Peripheral vascular conditions
Severe mental illness
Alzheimer's or related diseases
Hyperthyroidism

Patients suffering from or at high risk of dehydration e.g. pyrexial, diarrhoea, vomiting or other significant fluid losses; inadequate oral/ intravenous hydration. ( signs of dehydration: increased thirst, fatigue, dry oral mucosa, oliguria)
Certain dermatological conditions
Medications likely to provoke or increase the severity of heatstroke:
Those causing dehydration of electrolyte imbalance (diuretics and any drug which causes diarrhea or vomiting)
Those likely to reduce renal function (NSAIDS, Sulphonamides, Indinavir, ciclosporin)
Those with levels affected by dehydration (Lithium, Digoxin, antiepileptics, Biguanides, statins)
Those which interfere with thermoregulation
Drugs which exacerbate the effects of heat; and
Drugs which alter states of alertness
The effects of heat on health

The main causes of illness and death during a heatwave are respiratory and cardiovascular disease, the increase in respiratory problems is thought to be due to increased pollution, and with cardiovascular in order to keep cool, large quantities of extra blood are circulated to the skin. This causes strain on the heart, which for elderly people and those with chronic health problems can be enough to precipitate a cardiac event.
Additionally, there are specific heat related illnesses including:
Heat cramps –  caused by dehydration and loss of electrolytes, often following exercise.
Heat rash – small, red, itchy papules.
Heat oedema – mainly in the ankles, due to vasodilation and retention of fluid.
Heat syncope – dizziness and fainting, due to dehydration, vasodilation, cardiovascular disease and certain medications.

Heat exhaustion – is more common and is usually one of the first signs that someone is at risk. It occurs as a result of water or sodium depletion, with non-specific features of malaise, vomiting and circulatory collapse, and is present when the core temperature is between  and °C. Left
untreated, heat exhaustion may evolve into heatstroke. Symptoms include:
Headaches
Dizziness
Nausea and vomiting
Muscle weakness or cramps
Pale skin
Weak pulse, and
High temperature.
Low urine output
Cramping
un-coordination
Heatstroke –  can develop if the symptoms of heat exhaustion are left untreated and occurs when the body's thermoregulation mechanism fails.
Symptoms include:
Confusion and disorientation
Convulsions
Unconsciousness
Low/ no urine output
Cramping
Un-coordination
Racing, thumping pulse
Flushed hot and dry skin, and
Very sudden rise in temperature exceeding 40°C for between 45 minutes and 8 hours. It can result in cell death, organ failure, brain damage or death.
Patient areas which have active air cooling
9.9.1  The following patient areas should have active air cooling in place and could be used to accommodate patients that are vulnerable to extreme heat during heat waves:
Main theatre recovery areas.
ICU, ICC, HDU.
Burns ICU (Broomfield site)
Cardiac Centre recovery area.
Standalone procedure / treatment clinics.
Operating theatres.
Some specifically designed treatment / ward areas.
Heatwave advice
Environmental
Ensure that cool rooms are ready and consistently at 26ºC or below;
Check that indoor thermometers are in place (retained estate areas) and recording sheets printed to measure temperatures by ward staff four times a day.
Keep windows shut in patient areas, particularly within buildings prone to high sun exposure.
Identify naturally cooler rooms that vulnerable patients can be moved to if necessary;
Ensure that blinds remain closed on south facing windows during day time hours, and that windows are opened at night to utilise cooler night time air.

Identify particularly vulnerable individuals (those with chronic/severe illness, on multiple medications, or who are bed bound) who may be prioritised for time in identified cooler areas or specific cool rooms.
Ensure that all patients have easy and regular access to water

If fans are available and agreed for use by infection prevention, place near windows to assist air circulation but DO NOT point these directly at patients (infection prevention advice must be followed).
Ensure that staffing levels will be sufficient to cover the anticipated heatwave period.
Switch off any electrical equipment (including PCs) when possible.
Turn off lighting if safe to do so.
Keeping body temperatures down:
Extreme heat is dangerous to everyone. During a heatwave, when temperatures remain abnormally high over more than a couple of days, it can prove fatal.
To minimise the risk of heat related illness undertake the following:
Monitor patient's temperature and other observations more closely, especially if the patient condition has deteriorated.
Suggest regular cool showers or baths
keeping a damp cloth available to moisten skin and encourage evaporation of heat
Where work wear is down to the individual ;dress in light, loose, cotton clothing
Sprinkle water onto clothing to increase cooling
Eat cold foods, particularly salads and fruit with high water content
Drink regularly, preferably water or fruit juice; but avoiding alcohol and caffeine drink, particularly tea, coffee and cola's
With at-risk individuals, monitor fluid intake strictly.
Encourage patients to drink more fluids, use food charts to monitor input if necessary for more vulnerable patients
If at high risk or actually deteriorating, start a fluid balance chart and monitor inputs and outputs closely and inform medical staff of
abnormalities as a priority.
Promote a cooler environment by: shielding out sunlight by shutting blinds, opening windows, use fans (not directly pointing at patients) to create an air current.
Staff Care during a heatwave Do
Start work well hydrated and drink water frequently
Consider sports drinks for electrolyte replacement when sweating a lot
Take regular breaks
Keep an eye on patients and work colleagues
Avoid
Caffeinated drinks and heavy meals before or during work
Waiting for thirst before drinking water
Cold weather
A Cold Weather alert system operates in England from st November to the st  March, based on Metrological forecasts by the Met Office, which will
trigger levels of response from the NHS England / NHS Improvement, Public Health England and other bodies.

During this period, the Met Office will issue alerts which may forecast periods of severe cold weather on the basis of either of two measures: low temperatures of 2°C or less for at least 48 hours; and/or heavy snow and ice.
Example of a Cold Weather Watch Alert
The  Cold  Weather  Alert  service  comprises  five  main  levels  (levels  0-4) outlined below.
The  Trust  will  activate  specific  plans  according  to  cold  weather  alerts according to the alert level.
Generic actions at each level:
See appendix 3 for the action plan specific to role and departments.
Level 0: Long term planning
This is the long-term winter planning undertaken all year round, with particular considerations for resilience of staffing, estates and utility services.
Cold weather impacts should also be considered during the creation of other organisational planning programs, to include the staff flu vaccination program.
Level 1: Winter preparedness and action programme
Activities undertaken within this period to include;
Cold weather alerts distributed to the right staff and actions are agreed and implemented.
Staff flu vaccination program.
Staff and public advice accessible.
Room temperatures are considered and monitored.
Other winter preparedness programs undertaken as detailed within the system winter plans.
Level 2: Alert and readiness
Notification of a Cold Weather Alert at Level 2 is normally 2 to 3 days in advance actual Cold Weather.
Continue level 1 actions.
Public information leaflets to be made available to patients & visitors.
Staff awareness to be raised, identifying the significant health risks, potential increase inpatient admissions, staffing issues and any specific service continuity plans to be communicated.
Ensure road and pavement gritting arrangements are in effect to allow access to critical services
Expect surge in demand in near future.
Consider implementing the Internal Incident/business continuity plan.
Level 3: Severe
Continue level 2 actions.
The Strategic (Gold) and (Tactical (Silver) commanders should ensure that all services are regularly reviewed.
Implement the trust incident and business continuity plans.
Implement specific service continuity plans in addition to MEHT plan.
Ensure vulnerable people are contacted.
Level 4: Major Incident

A level 4 alert indicates that many parts of the country are experiencing exceptionally severe winter weather and the conditions are affecting critical services. Such weather conditions are likely to have significant impacts not only on health, but also on other sectors and critical infrastructures. A cross government, multi-agency response at national and regional level is required.
Continue level 3 actions.

Strategic (Gold) and Tactical (Silver) Commanders will receive further updates and information from NHS England regarding any required actions at Level 4 to support the response to the declared National Emergency.
Ensure Major Incident / incident Response Plans are implemented.
Situation reporting

In the event of a national or regional alert levels being triggered, all NHS Funded providers may be required to complete situation reports in order to give assurance that any identified actions have been undertaken, to ensure patient safety and continued service provision.
Multi-agency support

Should there be requests made by other agencies to the trust, where further support/ arbitration in the discussions is required; you should escalate these matters through the ordinary escalation process e.g. CCG and NHS England as required.

data.text: Appendix 5: Essex resilience forum (erf) 4x4 response capability in
cold weather
Essex Health 4x4 Response Procedure

In times of severe weather (heavy snow, flooding etc.), Essex Resilience Forum (ERF) have an agreed protocol with the Essex Rover Rescue Club to provide 4x4 support capability to emergency services and health for use in emergency situations.

4x4 support is not intended for routinely transporting members of staff between their home addresses and places of work, except in extreme circumstances where there is no viable alternative and the movement of these personnel is essential, at the time, for the saving and/or preservation of life. This should be catered for in an organisation's Business Continuity Plan. Where it is clear that the issue is an organisational business continuity issue, rather than fitting the criteria for support, it is liable to be rejected
There may be times when ‘health' may require support to undertake their duties and it would be appropriate for contact to be made to ECC requesting support through the Essex Rover Rescue Club.
In delivering 4x4 support across Essex the principal aims will be to:
Receive and prioritise requests for 4x4 assets.
Identify the 4x4 assets available.
Task 4x4 assets based on authorised requests and provide a scalable level of response to suit the incident requirements.
Monitor task completion and 4x4 resource welfare.
Ensuring that response/support can be provided safely during adverse weather and other incidents requiring a 4x4 response/support.
4x4 Support Criteria
As a general rule, 4x4 support will only be authorised:
Where life is at risk without an immediate response
Where life will be at risk without a response within  hours
Where there will be no risk to life within  hours, but physical or mental wellbeing may be affected.

Please note this criteria has been designed for life threatening situations. If this system is abused or misused, those needing urgent support may be placed at greater harm, in all circumstances please consider all other capabilities prior to requesting support.
When requesting 4x4 support, the requesting organisation must be clear what they require and why. Unless this clear from the outset, requests cannot be considered or authorised.
Trigger

In a no-notice incident, the initial tasking requests will be via the ECC Duty Officer on 07767 298483. If the demand for 4x4 support becomes so great that it becomes difficult for it to be managed in this way, then it will be escalated via a telephone conference with partners with a view to activating the 4x4 Cell.

The decision to activate the 4x4 Cell can be made by any ERF partner agency, and then agreed with other partners via a multi-agency teleconference. Where a Severe Weather Tactical Co-ordinating Group (TCG) has been set up, the initial request for activation of the 4x4 Cell should be made via the TCG. However, the absence of a TCG does not preclude the establishment of a 4x4 Cell to co-ordinate this activity.

The expected duration of the incident and anticipated scale will influence the decision making as activating the 4x4 Cell would have a lead-in time from moment of notice to being fully functional, which will also be dependent upon prevailing weather conditions.
For a pre-planned operation, the decision to activate the 4x4 Cell can be made in advance of the SCG by the appropriate strategic lead.

The criteria for forming the 4x4 Cell is whereby not forming it, there is significant potential for the response to be degraded leading to significant harm or risk to life. Should the demand for 4x4 resources exceed the county's available resources, mutual aid from other counties should be requested. If this occurs, a representative of the mutual aid provider should be encouraged to work within the 4x4 Cell.

Should mutual aid prove either insufficient or unavailable then a MACA request may be appropriate. Because of this, the inclusion of an MLO (Military Liaison Officer) within the 4x4 Cell should be considered at an early stage, particularly where the demand for 4x4 support has the potential to exceed normal supply. The only circumstance where Military support can be authorised by local Military commanders without a MACA request, is where there is an immediate danger to life.
A decision flowchart in respect of deciding whether or not a request for 4x4 support should be authorised is contained in Appendix A to this document.
Resources
In delivering 4x4 support across Essex, resources may come from a variety of sources. Some of these sources are outlined in Appendix B to this framework.
An overriding requirement of any 4x4 resource is that it must be capable of delivering a safe means of transport. To this end, it will be an absolute requirement that any such resources utilised are:
Are adequately trained in the use of their vehicles in all types of weather/road conditions.
Are fully aware of their capabilities as drivers and the capabilities of their vehicles.
Drivers must always operate within those capabilities.
Drivers of any resource utilised hold a valid driving licence for the class of vehicle.
Drivers of any resource utilised are covered by a current insurance policy that includes cover for the use that they and their vehicle are being put to.

There will be some instances where members of the community with 4x4 vehicles will spontaneously step forward offering their assistance. While such assistance may, at face value, seem useful such offers of assistance should be politely declined without adequate evidence of training, insurance cover, etc.

These resources should only be used where the situation clearly justifies it based on a balance of the increased risks involved. A risk assessment should be carried out and recorded prior to any use of this type of spontaneous volunteer capability.

In certain circumstances it may be possible to obtain additional 4x4 resources from Essex Police; Essex Fire & Rescue Service; and/or the Military. However, it should be borne in mind that these assets are limited in number and are primarily intended for the use of the owning service to deliver their core business.
Co-ordination
Tier 1 – Organisations' Own Business Continuity Arrangements

Where a single organisation is encountering weather related issues in relation to, but not restricted to, impacts on the safe delivery of their essential services, i.e. ability of staff to get to work, then this should be dealt with as a business continuity incident, and generally 4x4 support would not be appropriate to achieve this.
Tier 2 – Minor/Localised Incidents

For most minor incidents, for example where 4x4 support is required for a single or relatively small number of tasks in a small localised area, it is sufficient for the co- ordination to be managed by the ECC EP&R Duty Officer, or single agency co- ordination, working in close liaison with the Essex 4x4 Duty Controller.
Tier 3 – Widespread Incidents

Where an incident is likely to affect a wider area or will require a large number of 4x4 assets to make it sustainable over a prolonged period of more than 8 – 12 hours duration, then larger partners such as ECC or the NHS should establish their own internal co-ordination cell, which will take responsibility for managing their own priorities and then feeding the outcomes of this process into the 4x4 Cell.
For the purposes of this framework a “widespread incident” is defined as an incident significantly impacting more than one local authority area within the county.

It is essential that such larger partners draw up a prioritised list of their requirements in advance of an activation of any support as [art of their business continuity planning; and that these organisations work as a single unit within their own organisation to ensure effective co-ordination across their complex and conflicting structures/needs.

In the event that a decision is made not to convene a 4x4 Cell, then it will be the responsibility of an organisation, such as the NHS or ECC, to manage their own priorities to remove any conflicts and ensure effective utilisation of 4x4 resources.
Escalation

Where the incident impacts a wider area, for example widespread severe weather or flooding, it is likely to result in a high level of demand for 4x4 support, it is desirable that the co-ordination of such support is undertaken through a 4x4 Cell. Such a request does not have to be instigated by one of the “blue light” services. The establishment of a 4x4 Cell will enable all partners involved in the response to obtain a clear and concise common operating picture of the incident, and its demands upon resources.

Any ERF Category 1 partner organisation can request the convening of such a cell if they feel that it will be beneficial. Once this decision is taken it should be communicated to partners without delay so that an initial teleconference can be convened. The membership of the 4x4 Cell will include all partners with a vested interest in the incident, but at a minimum should include representatives from ECC Emergency Planning & Resilience; Essex Police; Health; Essex 4x4; and the DEPO Group.

It is desirable that a 4x4 Cell includes staff competent in using Resilience Direct so that both the logging and mapping functionality can be used to best effect. The agencies involved should nominate an appropriate Chair from amongst those involved.
Tracking of Resources

In a minor incident where one agency/authority is requesting 4x4 support, that agency/authority will be responsible for recording and tracking requests for support and the resources deployed to each request.

In a more widespread emergency, early consideration should be given to standing up the 4x4 Cell and this cell will be responsible for tracking resources. The decision as to how this will be managed will be the responsibility of the Tactical Commander (Silver), but it is suggested that this is best achieved through the establishment of the MAIC.
Reimbursement of Costs

Volunteer drivers should keep receipts for fuel used on emergency tasks. Funding for reimbursement of these costs will need to be agreed/confirmed on activation of this protocol by users; however, agencies should assume that journey costs will be attributed to the tasking organisation. All drivers should complete the Driver Journey Log at Appendix C, or similar, in order to ensure clear accounting of journeys made.
Health & Safety

Driving in severe weather conditions or ‘off road' can be hazardous. All volunteer drivers should be competent in the operation of their vehicles. It is the responsibility of 4x4 drivers to be aware of his/her ability and the limitations of the vehicle. Drivers and passengers should not be put at risk and if there is doubt about completing the allocated task, it should not be attempted, and the co-ordinator informed. It is the driver's responsibility to ensure that an appropriate rest period is taken between journeys. Vehicles should be fully fuelled and serviceable for the journey.
Safety Equipment
As a precaution, all 4x4 vehicles should carry the following equipment whilst deployed on emergency tasks:
A serviceable mobile phone & in car charger
Cold & wet protective clothing & boots
Shovel/snow shovel
Torch & spare batteries
Appropriate road atlas/maps or GPS
If available snow socks/chains or other traction aids should be carried.
Insurance
All 4x4 vehicles used in emergency support tasks should have appropriate insurance.
